I have roughly 20yrs of baby/toddler/child experience, and let me just tell you a few tricks that you might find helpful...

1) if your baby is crying for what seems like no reason, take them to the window/outside. I cannot tell you how many times I have done this and the baby is either now distracted from their fit or just very interested in seeing something other than the the house.

2) you discussed not being able to do what you want, and that's true to some extent, but there's a mommy secret which is to find activities of mutual enjoyment. You love mornings? Take your baby on a special walk when you wake up so you can really soak it in. There are so many options (especially as your baby moves out of mushy newborn phase) that you can find that fill both of your cups.

6 years after my first, and I’m almost done with my second pregnancy. I never had underarm odor until after I gave birth to my first. I also didn’t hardly have any armpit hair. Well that definitely changed. 😂 I’m so glad I’m not the only one.

I think it’s very individual, but for me the time solved most of my feelings and questions. I’m actually 2 days after my due date and because my baby girl wasn’t planned, it was very harsh to process the fact I’m going to be a mother😅 I really started to feel happy and calm when I was washing her tiny clothes ☺️ don’t worry, it’ll be okay🤍

Hi, you can also put 3-4 spoonfuls of breast milk in the baby bath, great for dry skin. Also a drop in each nostril if the baby has a blocked nose. It works wonders! For adults, it even helps with psoriasis!

😂 Can we clear up that your abdomen/tummy/belly etc felt sore and not your “stomach” or that your “stomach had an open wound.” ? Your uterus gets the wound from the exiting placenta. Your stomach is an organ within your abdomen - your “stomach” was not wounded and did not get an open wound. Took me a minute to understand what you were trying to convey. Kudos to you for talking about the fact that not everyone bonds to their baby immediately after birth, and that our partners might not right away either. I think it’s so important to be spoken about and so glad you’ve brought it up today. Well done Mama ❤️👏🏼

The placenta is attached to your cervix and that open wound is there definitely not in your stomach. There are cases of placenta attached to other body parts but these are dangerous pregnancies. For example if the baby attach itself to a fallopian tube you need to make an abortion fast or the tube will explode.

I wish I had known about the stomach stuff earlier! I am 22 weeks pregnant and I've already started having stomach issues. I love food, but now I have to figure out which foods cause me the least stomach pain. I am in my second week of staying home and just applied for short term disability because the pain is making normal functioning hard. Luckily I work a government job, so they've been putting up with my issues. They're pushing for a diagnosis though, and there is no readily apparent diagnosis for this issue (except for maybe the IBS umbrella term for undefined bowel issues). If this goes on for the rest of my pregnancy, I'm not sure how I'll retain my sanity. I was not aware of the postpartum stomach issues and I'm really not sure how I'll handle it if things get worse. I love my little bean more than my life, but I'll need some serious therapy once all the pregnancy and postpartum stuff is done.

People are't informed. Sometimes babies cry a lot without any apparent reason because the transition is TOUGH for THEM. They were in mom's belly heaven and landed brutally in this life where you have to breathe, feel hungry, feel your limbs uncontained, pee, poop, ... BABYHOOD IS TOUGH. Motherhood is challenging but that's not nearly as hard as being a newborn. People should be warned about this. The baby needs love and support all the time and when you hardly seep 4 hours per 24 hours and you absolutely need your sleep, you still have to support your baby and help him sleep and relax. It's really tough, especially the first three months when you're recovering from pregnancy and GIVING BIRTH. If men know how challenging this rally is, they'd be much more supportive and respectful of women in general.

Everything came back into place after 9 months PP for me... And after almost 2 years I'm feeling that my previous "state of mind" (personality if you prefer) is coming back. Let me just say: not all moms have that magical bond with their baby when they give birth, some of us take time to build that bond and that too is ok. ❤️

@Bryanna Nicole I'm sure you'll fall head over heels in love with your baby after getting to know them and taking care of them. ❤️ Some of us are careful and logical by nature and that might mean that falling in love at first sight is not an option, as much as you'd like it to be. It doesn't mean you don't care for your child, it just means that it takes a little time to form those heartshaped glasses for your eyes. 😁 Anyway, if it doesn't get better with time, talk to your doctor. Idk about her, but I know that I pretty much got back to my pre baby body within a week. Like, identical. According to my doctor, if your body is trained to be a certain way (strong) it will get back faster. It’s something you invest in pre-pregnancy. And I’m an athlete. Ive just noticed that a strong core pre-pregnancy and trained legs = almost always a faster recovery because that’s what you’re trained for. Just my experience! For reference, I’m 5 ‘ 5, 26 waist, size 2, ~128 pounds pre pregnancy.
Also not gaining too much weight during pregnancy is essential because they you end up losing most of the weight (except for like the extra ~5 pounds of stored fat for breastfeeding) during labor and within the 48 hours after (again, according to my doctor). Google pregnancy weight breakdown. I always tried to stay on the lowest/below the American lowest weight rec, because American doctors recommend a much higher weight gain than European doctors. I don’t think I ate any extra calories during pregnancy because my body just didn’t want to, but I have no idea, I always just eat intuitively. Hope this somehow helps! 💖💖 also remember, every body is different!

One thing I wasn't prepared for was breastfeeding. I truly believe if you intend to breastfeed, you should learn alot about lactation, latching forms, frequency of eating, pumping and the challenges one might face. Some women don't have any issues breastfeeding. I was in excruciating pain. It felt worse than the c-section. I cried and cried and felt like a failure. Your child may have a lip/tongue tie or you may be latching the child incorrectly. It is a learning process and isn't exactly innate (which i thought before I gave birth). I had to learn to be good at it and so did my son. I eventually gave up on breastfeeding at 5 months and became an exclusive pumper *which has its own learning curve. I believe my son still has some undiagnosed oral problems, which made breastfeeding very difficult for him. I noticed he wasn't very good at it BF no matter what I did and he was growing lethargic, which frightened the heck out of me. I just took him off the breast and bottle fed him breast milk. Which was the best the decision ever. Probably, something you should be mindful of - is when to stop pumping or breastfeeding. Alot of moms, including myself, place alot of pressure on themselves to BF as long as possible. I went to 18 months and had a stash left to get my boy to 20 months. In fact, i had so much excess milk, the deep freezer could not hold it all, so I ended up donating to 4 families on a regular basis. BF for so long really stressed me out. I workef full time and I was pumping around the clock (including logging everything). And I felt this huge burden to the ...milk. I know it is weird 😅 I should have stopped earlier. I suffered from sleep deprivation as well. My son still does not sleep through the night. He is a big boy (over the average weight and size) and he still needs a bottle in the night. So, I wish I had known more about the pressures of BF, pumping, sleep deprivation and sleep training before having my son.

Postpartum doula here!
I try and warn everyone about the smelly-ness, because so many are shocked. Smell is hormonal, and when you’ve just birthed a baby, your hormones are completely out of wack. It might go back to normal, but while you’re breastfeeding don’t expect it to. Becaaaaause your body also regulates your smell for your baby! In the early months your baby can’t see very well and they rely on your smell to know you. And your body ramping up your natural scent allows your baby to know/find you and your breasts. 😌
omgggg i had no idea 😮

comment: I also want to add that for breastfeeding... not all women lose weight just from breastfeeding! Some women don’t lose any weight at all and some actually gain weight! It’s definitely not a magic fix like a lot of people say.

YES!! People often forget that breastfeeding requires extra calories and like you said, it is definitely not a quick, weight loss fix. In fact, I wish women would not correlate breastfeeding with weight loss. Breastfeeding is so much more than that!

Were is the love button ❤ ! Thanks so much for this video! I’m 36 weeks and have done a bit of research into postpartum and thought I was pretty prepared but a few of these things were new to me!

On point girl :) 100% on all of these points! Honestly I was so naive before having my baby girl despite all the youtube newborn videos prep i watched or things I have read online.

I felt that watching sooo many videos on days "in the life with a newborn" or content in general was a bit of toxic for me. What I watched built my expectations and through my mommy journey I was broke them and found comfort in that with all the hot mess that it is.

I’m one of those mamas that didn’t have an immediate bond with my baby girl. I felt so guilty and didn’t actually feel attached to her for MONTHS! My husband had an immediate attachment. It was such an emotional rollercoaster. I thought I was an awful mom because no one ever talks about that so I’m glad you brought it up.

@Jenna Miller my baby is 1 month old abd i had cesarean. The pain and constant crying of the baby made me so sad and depressed. I couldn't bond at all. It was only after 2 weeks when i started breastfeeding a lot and my pain subsided and i could hold him more, i could feel the bond. This whole motherhood has been such a struggle for me. I would cry every evening the moment my baby's incessant crying spell would begin. No one talks about these.
Same here . I feelt so guilty and ashamed.  I thought it would be better to give my baby away to another mum  because Im a Bad mum  . Now my baby is 13 Months old and I love him more than everything.

I felt the same! It took me at least 4 months before i started to feel a bond forming i still feel like a crap mom for it :/ 10 months in and i still feel bad cus i know my bond isnt as strong as i see other moms with their babies :(
Same! I thought I was the only one. So glad to know I’m not alone

Same here because my first one was not planned (at least I think that’s why). Because I feel a lot more sentimental when I’m carrying the second baby because I wanted this one. I didn’t feel guilty though because I knew I would grow out and grow up to feel like a mom. I wasn’t mentally ready to be a mom back then, in fact I felt awkward telling him to call me mommy. Lol. It’s all good. This too shall pass. :)
